instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
slight water damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. replaced it and ran a trace from pin 20 to pin 3 of <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>. (corroded pad)

I get orange light.
ppbus is short to ground (.3ohms) and gets no voltage on pin 1 on <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
okay replaced f7140 and now i have .367v. 
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> is now at 5ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: PPBUS is short.....should that not the first thing to be fixed? That is probably what killed F7140 is the first place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: yes I know need to find the short, but couldn't find it.  put 8v 2amp on pin 2 of f7140.  nothing gets hot.  even tried cold spray.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Remove F7140 and check resistance on pins 1 and 2 of the fuse. If youâ€™re confident the short is on pin 2, something must absolutely be getting hot at 8 volts unless the short is inside the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
without the fuse pin 1 on f7140 gets 8v. pin 2 gets 0

with a new fuse pin 1 gets .44 pin 2 .386

i'm so confused.

ive tested with and without the fuse. spay and alcohol test. nothing heats up. i mean there arn't that many components on ppbus. i even removed all the caps and replaced them.  pin 2 is short to ground with .2ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Remove the fuse again because putting new fuses on with a shorted component is just going to keep killing your fuses.....This would indicate that your creation side of PPBUS is fine and the system side is shorted. Remember there is a lot on the system side such as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> and all the derivates of PPBUS. It could be any of the big caps, little caps, backlight fuse area, thunderbolt, etc. The one thing you don't want to be shorting it to ground is <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> because if it's shorted, then RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Inject voltage on pin 2 of the fuse or it will just blow the fuse. Crank up the voltage until you have 2-4 Amp current draw and then something must heat up. It could be the CPU so remove the heat sink and check that too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: is it okay to go past 8v?  thats what i was putting.  i have already taken off the fuse, should i put it back on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 8.6 volts is max. The reason you start low is to avoid sparking the CPU if it's dead. Don't put the fuse on until you find the short. Check all of the big caps for holes in the sides of them or any smoking.
